dialogue: Pardon me for intruding. I met this casting director - unique and unusual physiognomies is his specialty - he told me you were holding auditions for this interesting-sounding play, he thought I might perhaps be a proper fit. I’m no actor, but I thought I’d come take a gander. From the tidbit I’ve just seen, I must say it looks like a very curious piece! But I see the role is filled, and quite ably. Cheers to all involved. Best of luck. Break a leg, as they say. I’ll come see it when it opens. Good day!
Wait, hold on.
Do you two know each other?
I drunkenly descended upon him as he was celebrating with his real estate mates, a lovely bunch. I neglected to mention, I might be in the market for a flat myself.
Real estate mates?
I’m Oswald, by the way.
I’m Ingrid.
Ah, the brilliant scribe!
And director.
Ah, la maestra!
We’re just rehearsing, you should stick around and watch.
Ah, no, I fear I might develop a reputation for intruding where I’m not wanted.
Nonsense, you’re more than wanted! Though it’ll be nerve-wracking for us, the play is still nascent. Nothing set in stone.
Everyone’s so self-conscious in show business, I adore it. I confess I am intrigued by the whole process.
Well, you’re - please - unless you’re busy.
I just had my Jiu-Jitsu lesson, so I’m a tad sweaty, but otherwise, I was just going to read in the park.
What are you reading?
It’s called “The Bluest Eye,” by Toni Morrison.
One of my favorite books.
Strangely enough, I was inspired to read it by Guy. He has those piercing blue eyes, and I saw him, and thought “that reminds me...”
Funny, I never noticed your eyes, Guy. Well, have a seat anywhere you want. It’ll be boring. Stopping and starting...
You won’t know I’m here.
Okay. Where were we? Guy? Guy?
I was sad to see him off himself at the end.
It’s a tragedy.

Yes, I suppose there’s nothing to be done about it. I quite liked Edward, though he is a rather passive chap. At least until that suicide. Naturally, I wanted to see him live happily ever after with Fiona. Would the audience believe it?
That’s horrible.
It could use some mild refinement, but we’ll get there.
That’s brilliant. Why can’t you do that?
Well, you’re not playing Master Harold after all.
I guess they didn’t teach you accents at Juilliard.
Really Guy, I developed an affinity for them because I moved around a lot as a child. A survival instinct, really, which blossomed into one of my many useless talents.
What are your other talents?
Well, I can yodel - I can juggle. Children’s games, mere fluff. I can sing and play guitar, though I’m no Segovia. I’ve taken up weaving, I’m ashamed to say.
What can’t you do?
Oh, so many things. I can’t whistle.
I can teach you. You just -

Frankly, Guy, to keep you in the play. Look, this is hard for me but, you know I need Oswald to be Edward. And he refused unless there was a part for you, because he - loves you - and didn’t want it to be like he was...replacing you. And this is what we came up with. You should really be thanking Oswald.
Guy...
This is my decision. I had to beg him to do it. Look, it’s not you, Guy, but, come on, the mask, the makeup, it’s a total bust, and Oswald...I mean...
Ingrid insisted and...I admit, I do feel that this is a uniquely rare opportunity where I was, in a sense, born to play the role.
You’re selling yourself short. You could play Hamlet.
She’s a canny director, flattering me.
Frankly, Guy, we’ve been making all these changes and you’ve had trouble memorizing all the new lines.
I do have a photographic memory, technically, but it remains to be seen if that comes in handy in this department.
You already know your lines.
The lines, sure, but can I act? That is the question!
You can. He can. You’ve seen it. We’ve all seen it. Oswald’s a natural. If it’s right, it’s right.
Guy, you’re a masterful actor. That’s what’s so tragic here, and I really don’t know what the ethical thing is.
The right thing is for you to take the role. And Guy, you still get to play Edward...transformed...and you don’t have to hide your face behind that idiotic thing, so you’ll get more recognition.
The same person.
Same chap, new face.
I’m sorry, Guy. It doesn’t work. You said it yourself, how can he become you? You’re nothing alike. It’s not believable. And it’s not necessary. She loves him for who he is. It was contrived.

I still think the idea is theoretically sound, but what we didn’t count on, and this may stem from my being a novice, is how the audience has spent two hours becoming invested in Edward - that is, in this particular iteration of the piece, me - and if someone else comes out and says “Oh, I’m Edward now,” it doesn’t matter who it is, even if it’s Sir Kenneth Branagh or whomever, the audience feels cheated, we’ve broken our pact with the them, and they will rightfully rebel.
Look, I still want to be friends and I’ll keep you in for future projects. I’m sorry. Goodbye, Guy.
Have to do some shopping. Anyone need anything?
Well, I’m off. Anyone need anything?
I just asked.
Oh well, ring me if you do. Toodle￾loo.
I’ll walk you out.
Okay, we’ll get out of your hair. I’ll be back around eight.
We adopted Lucie, her daughter, who’s - it’s crazy to even say it - in grad school now.
Guy, you need to come see the show. When are you free? Tomorrow?
Don’t pressure him.
He wants to come. Right, Guy?
What a piece of shit. I don’t even allow people to perform it anymore.
Oh, come now. It was a very precocious “early work.” And it brought us together so it served a very noble purpose.
Thank God they didn’t make that movie.
I was disappointed, I wanted to see that guy play me. Anyway, you’ll love the new show. I think it’s her finest work.
Going out on a high note.
Time will tell. You see, it’s brilliant that we ran into you, because we’re leaving next month after the play wraps.
That’s only a small part of it, but yes, clothing is- I mean, it’s allowed, for visitors, and in winter, but...basically, we’ll be...
As the Lord intended us to be.
Traveling through the Andes.
- and it turns out she’s this amazing person, with followers and all that, and there’s a sort of ecological philosophy-
Plus free love.
Yes, but, also-
Not to mention, LSD.
Sometimes, yes, but...
Have you done LSD, Guy?
I’m not sure he could handle it.
He’d need a proper guide. Which I happen to be.
Recently certified.
They say it’s a cult.
I’m sure Guy thinks it’s a cult as well. Right, Guy?
The founder, yes. She set it in motion. Not a guru in the - well, a sort of guru, yes, in the purest sense. See, we can’t talk about it without sounding...
Totally bonkers.
Honestly, it’s, as far as I’m concerned, it’s paradise.
Paradise, it really is. Utopia, the closest thing.

Now she just wants to do LSD and fuck all the time! Anyway - he’s going to go home and tell his friends how batty we’ve become. I know how it sounds, that’s why I invite people up, people can see for themselves, and stay as long as they like. But what’s going on with you?
Tell us everything.
